MEM.label: Memory Awareness
MEM.description: Enforces correct behavior when context, memory, or continuity is limited or degraded.
inclusion_criteria: Applies when memory, continuity, or context loss is a concern.
Covers fallback behavior when memory is limited or disabled.
Governs disclosure or adaptation to degraded memory access.
exclusion_criteria: Does not cover formatting, hallucination, or execution validation.

LEN.label: Length & Truncation
LEN.description: Controls output length, mid-sentence cutoffs, and system streaming boundaries.
inclusion_criteria: Applies when responses are cut off mid-sentence or limited by token length.
Includes rules for truncation handling, streaming edge cases, and brevity enforcement.
exclusion_criteria: Does not include tone, style, or factual suppression.

REP.label: Redundancy & Echo
REP.description: Suppresses repeated instructions, disclaimers, or mirrored phrasing.
inclusion_criteria: Prevents repeated statements, disclaimers, or mirrored phrasing.
Covers echo suppression and over-acknowledgment of instructions.
exclusion_criteria: Does not include hallucinated content or speculative generation.

HAL.label: Hallucination Control
HAL.description: Prevents unsupported claims, fabricated details, or speculative reasoning.
inclusion_criteria: Suppresses unsupported, speculative, or fabricated content.
Covers hallucination prevention and source integrity.
exclusion_criteria: Does not include tone, repetition, or length enforcement.

FRM.label: Formatting & Structure
FRM.description: Requires specific output layout: tables, JSON, markdown, indentation, etc.
inclusion_criteria: Controls formatting of lists, markdown, tables, and structured output.
Includes layout rules and document structure constraints.
exclusion_criteria: Does not cover hallucination, memory state, or trust behavior.

TNS.label: Tone & Style
TNS.description: Constrains emotional tone, confidence, assertiveness, or voice.
inclusion_criteria: Requires disclosure of limits, uncertainty, or model constraints.
Includes confidence signaling and fidelity warnings.
exclusion_criteria: Does not include hedging tone or structural formatting.

RSP.label: Responsiveness
RSP.description: Ensures clear, complete, direct answers; prevents evasion or irrelevance.
inclusion_criteria: Covers default response behavior, such as tone, framing, and instruction reflection.
Includes interaction style and clarification strategy.
exclusion_criteria: Does not include memory use, factual correctness, or truncation.

ENF.label: Enforcement Discipline
ENF.description: Ensures other rules persist during truncation, degradation, or constraint.
inclusion_criteria: Ensures correct execution order, instruction following, and validation of input context.
Includes prevention of assumption-based behavior or speculative reasoning.
exclusion_criteria: Does not include stylistic tone, repetition, or memory optimization.

glossary.category: A behavioral grouping for TrueSignal rules based on their enforcement scope.
glossary.classification: The assignment of a rule to the category whose behavioral scope it best represents.

clarification_notes: Each rule must belong to exactly one category.
Do not classify based on formatting, metadata, or system implementation details.
When in doubt, select the category that governs the primary behavioral intent of the rule.
If a rule cannot be confidently placed, label it UNCLASSIFIABLE.

tie_break_order.reason: Execution and validation rules govern instruction-following behavior. These are foundational and override surface behavior like tone or output structure.
Preventing unsupported or speculative output is central to factual integrity and user trust.
Rules governing degraded memory or continuity influence whether the AI can maintain long-term behavioral expectations.
Token and truncation management affects whether output completes logically but does not alter factual or instructional behavior.
Suppressing repeated content enhances clarity but is less critical than maintaining accuracy or behavior.
Disclosure of limitations and model confidence is important but typically follows factual and behavioral integrity.
Response tone, framing, and clarification strategies shape interaction but do not determine correctness or trustworthiness.
Formatting and layout are important for clarity but are the least critical when resolving behavioral conflicts.

scoring.description: Each rule is scored based on how many inclusion_criteria it matches in each category. The category with the highest score is selected. If two or more categories tie, the first one listed in 'tie_break_order' is chosen. If no matches are found, the rule is labeled as UNCLASSIFIABLE.
